Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Readme] Images from untrusted domains are displayed in readmes" (#8459) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
Only images from trusted domains should be displayed. However, images from untrusted domains are still displayed for both embedded and legacy readmes.

For example:
* https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Loshar.Readme/3.0.0
* https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Loshar.Readme/4.0.0#

### To Reproduce

1. Upload a package that does not have an embedded readme
2. Add the following readme using the legacy readme feature: `![NuGet Logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/NuGet_project_logo.svg/220px-NuGet_project_logo.svg.png)`
3. Navigate to the package details page. The image is hosted by wikipedia.org which is not on the trusted domains list. It should not be rendered.

This also reproduces if you upload a package with the following embedded readme: `![NuGet Logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/NuGet_project_logo.svg/220px-NuGet_project_logo.svg.png)`

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[README]" (#8461) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### For issues regarding the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), file a bug on [NuGet Home](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues).

### Describe the bug

Clicking the Show More link clears the URL fragment and goes to the top of the page.

### To Reproduce

1. Go to https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/ICanHazReadme/1.0.1#show-readme-container
2. Click Show More
3. Wait a second

### Expected behavior

The README should expand but the viewport should stay where it is.

Actual: it jumps up.

### Screenshots

![repro](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/111713555-21536d00-880d-11eb-91f1-90fa6225b28b.gif)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[README] Empty embedded readme breaks the manage package > documentation section" (#8460) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug

I created a package with an empty README file. It seems to confuse the upload UI and the manage package Documentation section. It sort of looks like some of the code thinks it's a legacy readme package and other code thinks its an embedded readme.

### To Reproduce

Go here: https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/ICanHazReadme/1.0.2/Manage

Or

1. Create a nupkg with an embedded readme and make the readme empty (0 bytes)
2. Upload to Gallery
3. Notice the README preview on the upload package
4. After the package is uploaded, go to the Manage Package page and expand the Documentation section

### Expected behavior

Either the package should be rejected or the package should be considered to have an embedded readme and no Preview button should appear.

### Screenshots

No submit button:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/111712721-71c9cb00-880b-11eb-8ed0-5522618fd639.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Readme] Images from untrusted domains are displayed from legacy readme" (#8459) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### For issues regarding the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), file a bug on [NuGet Home](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues).

### Describe the bug
Only images from trusted domains should be displayed. However, images from untrusted domains are still displayed for legacy readmes.

For example: https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Loshar.Readme/3.0.0

### To Reproduce

1. Upload a package that does not have an embedded readme
2. Add the following readme using the legacy readme feature: `![NuGet Logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/NuGet_project_logo.svg/220px-NuGet_project_logo.svg.png)`
3. Navigate to the package details page. The image is hosted by wikipedia.org which is not on the trusted domains list. It should not be rendered.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[README] Show more +/- is shown even if there is no additional content" (#8458) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug

When the README is short (like 1-3 lines) the "Show more" / "Show less" links are shown but if you click on them they don't do anything.

### To Reproduce

1. Go to this package: https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/ICanHazReadme/1.0.0
2. Click "Show more" and "Show less"

### Expected behavior

The link should not appear for short READMEs.

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/111710428-ea7a5880-8806-11eb-94b3-ef11fe2a20b1.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Readme] UTF8 characters broken in preview but work in expanded mode" (#8457) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
UTF8 characters do not render properly in the README preview.

### To Reproduce

1. Go to: https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Loshar.Readme/2.0.0#
1. Look at the Documentation (notice the ?):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/737941/111708733-a2a60200-8803-11eb-8f53-0bb94d04f4d8.png)

1. Now press `+ Show more` (notice the emojis):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/737941/111708768-afc2f100-8803-11eb-8a12-5dcb69b2a733.png)

### Expected behavior
UTF8 emojis should work in the preview mode.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Stats: Community Packages shows non-Community Packages #2" (#8456) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug

The Community Packages shows non-Community Packages, see screenshot



url: https://www.nuget.org/stats/packages

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. go to https://www.nuget.org/stats/packages


### Expected behavior
Not showing Microsoft packages when "Show all packages" isn't checked. Currently 3 microsoft.* packages are shown

### Screenshots

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5808377/111561543-e9a8de80-8794-11eb-9d5c-0a7e3b9e43b6.png)



related: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7314

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Revert "Fix 3107 - Gallery UTs take a long time to finish."" (#3880) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "[Feature Request] Private feeds locked by an ApiKey" (#8455) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Current NuGet gallery is for public consumption - it's like a single, PUBLIC feed. 

Would love to have a the ability to create private feeds, locked by api keys (which already exist).

Currently we could:
- Use one of the -other- nuget server implementations that exist but this means we need to manage them (which most people don't need to want to manage anything, these days)
- Use a commercial product. This is good for businesses that making a profit/want extra security+complience/advanced features/etc ... but there's still a section of the community that don't need all of that and/or don't make money (but still would like private feeds).

So it would be really awesome if this could be a feature that could be considered.


(This idea was raised in #8314 )

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Manage NuGet packages for solution extremely slow" (#10674) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/Manage-NuGet-packages-for-solution-extre/1371226)._ --- [severity:It's more difficult to complete my work] [regression] [worked-in:16.7 (I think)] After installing the latest version of Visual Studio 2019, the Manage NuGet packages for the whole solution is terribly slow. I have a solution with 70+ projects in it, and in previous versions I had no issue when managing the NuGet packages for the solution. But now, when opening, Visual Studio freezes for some minute or so, and after that it needs even more time to load the information of the NuGet packages. When all is done, it again takes some 20 seconds when I select a new NuGet package to see its information. Also, switching from package source freezes the GUI and is very slow. CPU usage for Visual Studio normally is around 15% (when doing nothing), but it peeks at 40% when opening the Nuget Package manager for the solution. Also the network traffic goes to 100% for a few seconds. --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 3/16/2021, 06:51 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "dotnet restore fails, but reports success" (#10606) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

Cross posting from dotnet sdk, as it isn't clear if this issue is in the sdk or the nuget client used in that sdk.
Repro posted on https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/16031#issuecomment-786748923

Product version: 

dotnetsdk 3.1.406

## Repro steps and/or sample project

Repro is simple. Try to restore a package that doesnt exist. E.g. Microsoft.Build.Traversal2

```
aaronla@aaronla-rabbit:MyRepo$ dotnet restore
X:\MyRepo\dirs.proj : error : Unable to find package Microsoft.Build.Traversal with version (= 2.999.1)
X:\MyRepo\dirs.proj : error :   - Found 24 version(s) in MyCustomFeedOne [ Nearest version: 3.0.0 ]
X:\MyRepo\dirs.proj : error :   - Found 0 version(s) in MyCustomFeedTwo

aaronla@aaronla-rabbit:MyRepo$ echo %ERRORLEVEL%
0
```

### Verbose Logs

<!-- Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...) -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash] Package recommendor gave a wrong package-installing suggestion to C++ UWP project" (#10673) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.10.0.7170
VS Version: Main\31118.282
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-20h1
## Repro steps and/or sample project
1. Launch VS and click “Create a new project” button in the G2C dialog.
2. Create a Blank App (Universal Windows – C++/CX) template.
3. Open the PM UI of the project and go to “Browse” tab.
4. Try to install the first package “Newtonsoft.Json” suggested by the package recommendor (there is a start icon on the left of the suggested package name).
## Expected
Package recommendor should give a correct package-installing suggestion to C++ UWP project.
## Actual
Package recommendor gave a wrong package-installing suggestion to C++ UWP project as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/111754036-7d33f980-88d2-11eb-9dac-0850f5ec18d6.png)
## Note
It seems not a regression issue since it repro on 16.9 GA (D16.9\31025.194).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash] PM UI doesn’t sort correctly when searching a package whose name have the string “wcf” in WCF Service Application project" (#10672) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.10.0.7170
VS Version: Main\31118.282
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-20h1
## Repro steps and/or sample project
1. Launch VS and click “Create a new project” button in the G2C dialog.
2. Create a C# WCF Service Application (.NET Framework 4.8) template.
3. Open the PM UI of the project and search “wcf” in the filter of “Browse” tab.
## Expected
PM UI should put the packages whose name have the string searched at the top of the list.
## Actual
PM UI didn’t put the packages whose name have the string searched at the top of the list as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/111753734-2c240580-88d2-11eb-91cc-65fd71c22dc4.png)
## Note:
It seems not a regression issue since it repro on 16.9 GA (D16.9\31025.194).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash] Error “operation canceled by user” show in Error List window when switching between tabs quickly in PM UI" (#10671) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.10.0.7170
VS Version: Main\31118.282
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-20h1
## Repro steps and/or sample project
1. Launch VS and click “Create a new project” button in the G2C dialog.
2. Create an ASP.NET Web Application (.NET Framework 4.8) ->Single Page Application.
3. Open the PM UI of the project and switch between the “Browse”/”Installed”/”Updates” tabs a little quickly.
## Expected
No error show in Error List window and the tab switch correctly.
## Actual
Error “operation canceled by user” show in Error List window as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/111753404-cc2d5f00-88d1-11eb-9e95-fdba7385578d.png)
## Note
Not a regression since it start to repro from the PR: Updating via Checkboxes no longer causes Null Reference Exception NuGet/NuGet.Client#3864

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug Bash] Only the embedded license content of the latest version can be loaded correctly in PM UI when there are multiple versions in the same package" (#10670) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.10.0.7170
VS Version: Main\31118.282
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-20h1
## Repro steps and/or sample project
1.	Create a Class Library (.NET Framework 4.8) in VS and build the solution. 
2.	In the Developer Command Prompt for VS, cd to the project path and create a nuspec file by executing command “nuget spec”. 
3.	Make an image file (size limited to 1 MB with PNG format and 128x128 resolution) and locate in the package. 
4.	Make a License.txt and locate in the package. 
5.	Add following to nuspec file 
```
<package> 
  <metadata> 
    ... 
    <icon>images\icon.png</icon> 
    <license type="file">License.txt</license> 
  </metadata> 
  <files> 
    ... 
    <file src="[ProjectPath]\icon.png" target="images\" /> 
    <file src="[ProjectPath]\License.txt" target="" /> 
  </files> 
</package> 
```
6.	Pack the package to local path by executing command “nuget pack”. 
7.	Pack the same package with another version following step3-step6.
8.	Create a C# Console App (.NET Framework 4.8) in VS and open PM UI of the project/solution. 
9.	Add the package source as a local feed in Settings->NuGet Package Manager->Package Sources. 
10.	Select the new added local feed in the Package source dropdown box in the PM UI and click the package on the left panel.
11.	Choose a package version in the “Version” drop-down box on the right panel and click the “View License” link of every version. 
## Expected 
The embedded license content of every version can be loaded correctly in the PM UI.
## Actual
Only the embedded license content of the latest version can be loaded correctly as below.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/111753067-604af680-88d1-11eb-89e0-9ffa910967f2.png)
## Notes
1.	Repro on both project-level PM UI and solution-level PM UI.
2.	Not a regression since it start to repro from the beginning of the embedded license feature in dev-rrelyea-remotefileservice\5.9.0.14330.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Make "dotnet list package" also list packages referenced as MSBuild project SDKs" (#10669) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | Visual Studio | MSBuild.exe | dotnet.exe): dotnet.exe

Product version: .NET SDK 5.0.201

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: AFAIK, no

## Repro steps and/or sample project

demo.msbuildproj references [Microsoft.Build.NoTargets/2.0.1](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Build.NoTargets/2.0.1) as an [MSBuild project SDK](<https://docs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/msbuild/how-to-use-project-sdk?view=vs-2017#how-project-sdks-are-resolved>):

```XML
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.Build.NoTargets/2.0.1">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>netstandard2.0</TargetFramework>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="docfx.console" Version="2.56.6" ExcludeAssets="all" GeneratePathProperty="true" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

Run the command `dotnet list demo.msbuildproj package`.  Output:

```
Project 'demo' has the following package references
   [netstandard2.0]:
   Top-level Package             Requested   Resolved
   > docfx.console               2.56.6      2.56.6
   > NETStandard.Library   (A)   [2.0.3, )   2.0.3

(A) : Auto-referenced package.
```

I'd like to see `Microsoft.Build.NoTargets 2.0.1` included in the output, for license audit purposes.

### Verbose Logs

Adding `--verbosity diag` does not change the output.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Pack from Visual Studio doesn't work with embedded readme" (#10668) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: Visual Studio
Product version: private build 5.10.0.7298
https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/_apis/resources/Containers/7402507/VS15?itemPath=VS15%2FNuGet.Tools.vsix

## Repro steps and/or sample project

1. Create a SDK-based project (class library targeting .NET Standard 2.0 is easy way)
1. Create a README.md file in the .project
1. Open the .csproj and edit it to look something like this:

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>netstandard2.0</TargetFramework>
    <PackageReadmeFile>README.md</PackageReadmeFile>
  </PropertyGroup>
  
  <ItemGroup>
    <None Include="README.md" Pack="true" PackagePath="\"/>
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

Right click on the project node and click Pack.

Look in the produced .nupkg for a README.md ✔️ and for a `<readme>` element in the .nuspec ⚠️.

The file is there but the .nuspec is not having the `<readme>` element.

Here is my example project: [ICanHazReadme.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/6167766/ICanHazReadme.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package Namespaces Proposal" (#55) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Introduction of a feature concept called Package Namespaces which allows a developer to include or exclude package IDs by specifying package namespaces on their package source(s).

🎉📦Please provide your comments, concerns, and feedback within this PR. 📦🎉

https://github.com/NuGet/Home/pull/10660

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Custom V2 OData queries will be deprecated March 9th, 2021 " (#54) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (#37) last year and conducted a dry run of the deprecation to ensure that there are no surprises for users (#40). 

We will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in March 9, 2021, as detailed in [the blogpost here](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/custom-v2-odata-queries-will-be-deprecated-march-9-2021/).

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post.](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021" (#53) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by March 15th, 2021 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/
